c74object.name: dada.base
c74object.description: Implements a database supporting lllls (and hence scores), as well as standard Max data types.

outlet.digest: Bang when an external file has been properly loaded

objarg.name: name
objarg.description: The first arguments sets the database name. If the name is not set, an unique name will be assigned to the database.

objarg.name: filename
objarg.description: The second argument, if set, sets the database filename. If such argument is set, the database is automatically read from the file and saved in the file whenever the patch is saved. If the name provided terminates with the ".db3" extension, the database is stored as a standard native SQLite3 database, which guarantees the best performance at reloading. Otherwise, the database is saved as in bach textual form.

method.name: (doubleclick)
method.description: Doubleclicking on the object opens a text editor, where the whole database can be edited directly in text form. To prevent unwanted long hangs, this is only true for small datasets: if you need to open large datasets in text form, please use the wopen message explicitly.

method.name: (drag)
method.description: The specified file is read from disk and the database it contains (as llll) is opened.

method.name: adddistanceentry
method.digest: Add an entry to a distance table
method.description:
Example: addentry disttowns towns name NewYork Buffalo 601 → add in "disttowns" the information about the distance between NewYork and Buffalo (idenfitied by their name inside the table "towns".
An adddistanceentry adds an entry in a distance table. Syntax is adddistanceentry distance_table_name reference_table_name reference_column_name column_value1 column_value2 distance.

method.name: adddistanceentry
method.digest: Add an entry to a distance table
method.description:
Example: addentry disttowns towns name NewYork Buffalo 601 → add in "disttowns" the information about the distance between NewYork and Buffalo (idenfitied by their name inside the table "towns".
An adddistanceentry adds an entry in a distance table. Syntax is adddistanceentry distance_table_name reference_table_name reference_column_name column_value1 column_value2 distance.

method.name: adddistancetable
method.digest: Add a distance table to the database
method.description:
Example: adddistancetable disttowns towns → add a distance table named "disttowns" designed to contain distances of elements from the table "towns".
An adddistancetable message followed by a table name and the name of a reference table will add a table designed to contain distances between the entries of the reference table. Distances should be then added via adddistanceentry.

method.name: addentry
method.digest: Add an entry to a table
method.description:
Example: addentry towns [name NewYork] [population 8406000] → add an entry in the table "towns".
An addentry message followed by a table name and some entry specification will add an entry to the table (if existing). Entry specification be in the form [columnname1 content1] [columnname2 content2]... .

method.name: addtable
method.digest: Add a table to the database
method.description:
Example: addtable towns [name s] [population i] → add a table named "towns" with two columns: name (symbol) and popuplation (integer)
An addtable message followed by a table name and some columns specifications will add a table to the database having the given number and types of columns. Column specification must be in the form [name1 type1] [name2 type2]... where each name is a symbol and each type is one of the symbols: "f" (float), "i" (integer), "s" (symbol), "r" (rational), "p" (pitch), "l" (llll).

method.name: appendfromfile
method.digest: Appends entries to table from file
method.description:
Appends the content of a given text file (second argument) to a table (first argument). The file should contain a properly formatted llll in the form ENTRY1 ENTRY2..., where each ENTRY is in the form [[column_name value[s]] [column_name value[s]]...].
If a third specification of the kind [cols colname1 colname2...] is set, only the specified columns will be imported into the database.
If you have a massive amount of symbol entries in your table, this should be the preferred method of loading them into a dada.base object, since it bypasses the Max symbol table, inserting strings directly into the SQLite database.

method.name: clear
method.description: A clear message will delete all entries from all tables. If a table name is specified as a second argument, only the entries of such table are deleted.

method.name: deletetable
method.description: A deletetable message followed by a table name will delete such table (if it exists) from the database.

method.name: dump
method.description: Outputs the entire database in llll form (also outputs the column names depending on the outputcolnames attribute). Syntax is: TABLE1 TABLE2..., where each table is [TABLE_HEADER TABLE_CONTENT], where TABLE_HEADER is [table_name [column_name1 column_type1] [column_name2 column_type2]...] and TABLE_CONTENT is [[table_id_name id] [field1_name content1] [field2_name content2]...] and the table_id_name name is the singularized version of the table name, with the "_id" suffix (e.g. for a table named "waves" this will be "wave_id").

method.name: erase
method.description: An erase message will delete all tables and all entries in the database.

method.name: getcols
method.digest: Output column names and types as llll
method.description: Outputs the table header for each table in the database, i.e. the column names and types. Syntax is: TABLE1 TABLE2..., where each table is [table_name [column_name1 column_type1] [column_name2 column_type2]...]

method.name: query
method.description: Sends a query to the database. The query result will be output from the first outlet.

method.name: read
method.description: The specified file is read from disk and the llll it contains is set as current database. In order to have the correct syntax, the llll must be as the one written by write or writetxt messages.

method.name: wopen
method.description: The wopen message will open a text editor for the database.

method.name: write
method.description: A write message will save the database (as llll) in a file, in native format. If an argument is given, this is the filename (if the file is in the search path or in the same folder) or the full file path. If no argument is given, a dialog window pops up. Syntax is expected to be in the format explained in the dump message documentation.

method.name: writetxt
method.description: A writetxt message will save the database (as llll) in a file, in text format. If an argument is given, this is the filename (if the file is in the search path or in the same folder) or the full file path. If no argument is given, a dialog window pops up. Syntax is expected to be in the format explained in the dump message documentation.

attribute.name: escapesinglequotes
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to escape single quotes in symbols when adding entries. Defaults to 1.

attribute.name: name
attribute.description: Sets the name of the database

attribute.name: nulltodefault
attribute.digest: Convert null lllls to Default Values
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to convert null lllls to default values, for columns of type int, float and symbol. Default is on. If you turn this off, the null lllls will result in NULL SQLite fields.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Convert null lllls to Default Values

attribute.name: outputcolnames
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to output the column names in query answers. Defaults to 1.

attribute.name: volatile
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to make the database read-only.

entry.name: Outlet 2 (bang)
entry.description: Bang when an external file has been properly loaded.
